review.title: The Hebrew Bible as Data: Laboratory - Sharing - Experiences
review.abstract: The systematic study of ancient texts including their production, transmission and interpretation is greatly aided by the digital methods that started taking off in the 1970s. But how is that research in turn transmitted to new generations of researchers? We tell a story of Bible and computer across the decades and then point out the current challenges: (1) finding a stable data representation for changing methods of computation; (2) sharing results in inter- and intra-disciplinary ways, for reproducibility and cross-fertilization. We report recent developments in meeting these challenges. The scene is the text database of the Hebrew Bible, constructed by the Eep Talstra Centre for Bible and Computer (ETCBC), which is still growing in detail and sophistication. We show how a subtle mix of computational ingredients enable scholars to research the transmission and interpretation of the Hebrew Bible in new ways: (1) a standard data format, Linguistic Annotation Framework (LAF); (2) the methods of scientific computing, made accessible by (interactive) Python and its associated ecosystem. Additionally, we show how these efforts have culminated in the construction of a new, publicly accessible search engine SHEBANQ, where the text of the Hebrew Bible and its underlying data can be queried in a simple, yet powerful query language MQL, and where those queries can be saved and shared.

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text: This year is the highest in the history of the country.

sections.heading: 2. Ground work: WIVU and ETCBC
sections.text: Since the 1970s, Eep Talstra, Constantijn Sikkel and a group of researchers at the VU Amsterdam have compiled a text database of the Hebrew Bible. This database began as a series of files containing the transcribed Hebrew text of the Bible after the Biblia Hebraica edition (Kittel 1968-1997). To this text, they added files with their observations of linguistic patterns to them as coded annotations, they tested the individual words, phrases, clauses and sentences, they refined the timid patterns against the data and added manual exceptions, resulting in a complex network of files containing the semi-automatically generated annotations. They have summarized these annotations in a form of annotations that are centric.

sections.text: In 2013-2014, ETCBC and DANS carried out the CLARIN-NL project SHEBANQ. We took the opportunity to implement the idea of queries-as-annotations, but more needed to be done to make it possible.

sections.heading: Acknowledgements
sections.text: The following people have contributed substantially to the work described in this paper in very different ways: my colleagues at DANS: Henk Harmsen and Andrea Scharnhorst for providing additional time for research on these topics; Henk van den Berg and Heleen van de Schraaf for developing basic parts of the web service and web application of SHEBANQ; the ETCBC people: Eep Talstra and Constantijn Sikkel for creating and maintaining the ETCBC database and sharing so much knowledge about it; Wido van Peursen for providing the pathway for increased data sharing; Oliver Glanz for showing order in the forest of features of the database; Gino Kalkman and Martijn Naaijer for using the new tools and challenging me. Grietje en Johan Commelin for their efforts to make LAF-Fabric work in the cloud. Reinoud Oosting for finding subtle new cases for the introduction of JansHEQ and Dynamics.

referenceMentions.context: This story has a beginning in February 2012, when a group of biblical scholars convened at the Lorentz center at Leiden for the workshop Biblical Scholarship and Humanities Computing: Data Types, Text, Language and Interpretation (Roorda et al. 2012).
During the aforementioned Lorentz workshop (Roorda et al. 2012), an international group of experts reflected on how to bring biblical data resources to better fruition in the digital age.
A very concrete articulation of this statement was made by Eep Talstra himself, when he deposited the ETCBC database into EASY, the research archive of DANS (Talstra et al. 2012).
The idea to create LAF-Fabric arose after we tried to use a library called graf-python (Bouda 2013-2014), part of POIO (Bouda et al. 2012), for the biblical LAF data.
